titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jim Dow photographs, 1966-2019 RL.11709
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-28 08:59:24 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Jim Dow (1942- ) is an American photographer based in Massachusetts. The core of the collection consists of approximately 1905 black-and-white and color sheet negatives, representing images taken by Dow from 1966 to 2018. These are accompanied by a large set of teaching slides and electronic files for his art and photography courses. Dow's photographs feature 20th century U.S. vernacular architecture and landscapes in New England, the U.S. West, Midwest, and the South, with a focus on North Dakota and Massachusetts; multi-panel panoramas of sports stadiums and athletic fields, chiefly in the U.S. and U.K.; and the architecture and interiors of private clubs, libraries, and large public buildings such as churches and museums in cities around the world. Also featured is a series on food trucks and taco trucks, chiefly in the U.S. and Mexico. Other important travel images were taken in Argentina and Uruguay. Regardless of location, many of Dow's photographs include outdoor advertising and cultural expressions such as murals, handpainted signs, bar decor, and graffiti; people are rarely present. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

physdesc.dimensions: The majority of the negative sheets measure 8x10 inches, with the remainder measuring 4x5 inches.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series: Negatives; Teaching Slides; and Teaching Files (electronic format). The negatives are arranged in rough chronological sequence and by bodies of work. Within these groups, the negatives are organized by the photographer's original identifiers.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Film negatives (first series) are closed to research. Please contact the Rubenstein Library for more information.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The electronic files are in process and are currently closed to use.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial use. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Jim Dow photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2019 and 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Jim Dow photographs, 1966-2019, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: All negatives were developed on safety film. The majority are in color; black-and-white negatives bear the earliest dates.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and described by Paula Jeannet and Alanna Styer. Completed August 2019.
Addition (2020-0063) processed and described (box level) by Paula Jeannet, January 2021.
Accession(s) represented in this collection guide: 2019-0030, 2020-0063.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The core of the collection consists of approximately 1905 black-and-white and color film negatives by photographer Jim Dow, representing images taken from 1966 to 2018. The images document Dow's extensive travels chiefly in Argentina, Uruguay, England, Mexico, across much of the United States, and to a lesser extent in Canada, Portugal and Scotland. The great majority of the photographs were shot with an 8x10 inch view camera and color film; the black-and-white negatives typically measure 4x5 inches and represent Dow's earliest work.

Dow is best known for his studies of U.S. 20th century vernacular architecture and landscapes in New England, the U.S. West, the Midwest, and Southern States; for his multi-panel panoramas of baseball, football, and soccer stadiums and athletic fields, chiefly in the U.S. and U.K.; and for his images of the architecture and interiors of private clubs, libraries, and large public buildings such as churches, museums, and civic buildings in cities around the world.

The earliest photographs in the collection were taken in almost every region of the lower 48 states, beginning in 1966 and continuing through 2018. Starting out in black-and-white then soon transitioning to color, they document small towns and roadside attractions, well-worn business fa√ßades, and gathering places such as barbequeue joints, bars, event halls, and diners. North Dakota features prominently, as do California, Louisiana, Massachusetts, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Texas, Virginia, and Wyoming. There is also a series on food trucks and taco trucks in the U.S., Mexico, and South America. Regardless of location, many of Dow's photographs include details of outdoor advertising and cultural expressions such as murals, handpainted signs, bar decor, and graffiti; people are rarely present.
Also included are photographs representing Dow's commissioned work (1985-2008), chiefly taken at New England universities and private schools such as MIT, Yale, Tufts, Vassar, and Phillips Academy.

Accompanying the negatives archive is a large set of approximately 120,960 teaching slides and hundreds of electronic files related to Dow's photography and art courses, dating from approximately 1980 to 2019.
These materials form the first two installments of the photographer's archive at Duke University. Additions of photographic prints and professional papers are anticipated.

did.physdesc: Original identifiers generally consist of the year taken and a two-digit number; after the 1970s the photographer's initials (jdd) preface all identifiers but are not expressed in this inventory. A few of the earliest identifiers may not always include the year, but others have been standardized to this system. Because the negatives represent a selection from the total career output, there are frequent gaps in numbering.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Negatives are closed to research. Please contact the Rubenstein Library for more information.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: A duplicate set of negatives is held by the photographer.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Negatives were assigned original titles and identifiers and housed in sleeves and folders by the photographer and assistants; additional rehousing and enhanced folder-level description was performed by library staff, May-July 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Locations include: Roxbury, Belmont, Boston, Clinton, Revere, Cape Cod, MA; Pungoteague, VA. Black-and-white 4x5 inch negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Locations include: Uxbridge and Belmont, MA; Quebec; Chesapeake and Danville, VA; Ballouville, CT; Bronx, N.Y. Many of these photographs are portraits of people. Both 4x5 and 8x10 inch sizes. Large sizes appear to be reprints of 1969 4x5 inch negatives. Black-and-white.

did.unittitle: Photography and Art History teaching slides

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Color and black-and-white film transparencies (mounted slides)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of a large archive of approximately 120,960 color and black-and-white slides used by photographer Jim Dow to teach courses on photography and art history, chiefly at Harvard, Tufts, and the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Some may also document exhibit installations or other programs and collections. The slide transparencies are housed in slide boxes within 76 larger flat boxes; each box is estimated to hold approximately 2160 slides.
Contents of the series as currently known include:

-Slides used in History of Photography courses: 62 boxes (16.5 x 18.5 x 3 inches). Organized by artist/photographer or topic and includes a large set of slides with images relating to the history of photographic processes.
-Slides used in Contemporary Art History courses: 12 boxes, (16.5 x 18.5 x 3 inches)
-Slides used in Contemporary Art History courses: 1 box, nonstandard size
-Slides of Jim Dow's own work, 1 small box marked JDD
-Canadian Center for Architecture slides and albums/catalogs: 1 box

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This series has been given baseline processing by library staff. A detailed inventory of the slides boxes is currently in process and will be made available.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted. Collection is in process and is currently closed to use as of 10/2020.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are currently in process and are closed to use. Please contact the Rubenstein Library for more details.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These electronic files are related to Jim Dow's courses on the history of photography and contemporary art. Contents may include syllabi, notes, lectures, and bibliographies. Dates are approximate. Student work is not included.
